{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3283230,"name":"Jenna A.","username":"pixelprp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/f17d59/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-13T15:57:01.246Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone! Currently looking for a good beam-sensor to detect when a robot intakes an object, stores it, and then releases the object. Does anyone have any good suggestions for sensors they’ve used in the past or have heard good things about?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-01-13T15:57:01.246Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":161.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":449889,"topic_slug":"any-suggestions-for-good-beam-sensors","display_username":"Jenna A.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63059,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/any-suggestions-for-good-beam-sensors/449889/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3283240,"name":"Nicholas ","username":"unident","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unident/{size}/188354_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-13T16:02:47.703Z","cooked":"

This season, we plan to use this 5mm LED beam break sensor from Adafruit, off a recommendation from another team. They’re stupid cheap compared to most industrial automation related products, and much more compact and easier to package in theory.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-01-13T16:02:47.703Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":71.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":449889,"topic_slug":"any-suggestions-for-good-beam-sensors","display_username":"Nicholas ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.adafruit.com/product/2168","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : $5.95 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits","clicks":45}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/any-suggestions-for-good-beam-sensors/449889/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283248,"name":"Jenna A.","username":"pixelprp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/f17d59/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-13T16:09:50.978Z","cooked":"

Thank you for the suggestion, I’ve been hearing a lot about these specific type of sensors. I know this is not always the case but do you know if the cheap price indicates any lack in quality?

Favorite Beam Break Sensors Electrical
What beam break sensors are folks using currently? Do you like them? We’ve used these Banner QS18VN6LV sensors in the past on robots though have noticed some smaller and more compact versions on robots recently. Another bonus might be sensors that can operate at 5V, though I’d expect most industrial parts will be similarly 12-24V-range.

No problem. It is lower cost due to it being pretty simple, not poorer quality. To my knowledge, and in my experience, adafruit has a good reputation with quality.
